question: What is the name of the place in The Chronicles of Narnia where Lucy Pevensie and Mr. Tumnus meet?

nodes.instruction: Identify the book series 'The Chronicles of Narnia' and the characters Lucy Pevensie and Mr. Tumnus.
Retrieve the specific book or context in 'The Chronicles of Narnia' where Lucy Pevensie first encounters Mr. Tumnus.
Locate the place or location description from the context where Lucy Pevensie meets Mr. Tumnus for the first time.

graph.explanation: The execution graph breaks down the task of determining the place where Lucy Pevensie and Mr. Tumnus meet into manageable steps. Initially, we identify the relevant book series and characters (Node 1). Next, we retrieve the specific context in 'The Chronicles of Narnia' where the characters meet (Node 2). Lastly, we analyze this context to pinpoint the specific location of their meeting (Node 3), synthesizing the information needed to answer the query.

retrieved_passages:
Lantern Waste
Lantern Waste is a fictional place in "The Chronicles of Narnia" series by C. S. Lewis. It is a wood and is notable as the place where Lucy Pevensie and Mr. Tumnus meet, which is the first scene of Narnia described in the books. The lamppost in the wood is an iconic image of Narnia, and the question of its origin is what convinced Lewis to write more than one book on Narnia. One of King Edmund's titles is "Duke of Lantern Waste".

Mr. Tumnus
Tumnus is a fictional character in C. S. Lewis' series "The Chronicles of Narnia". He is featured prominently in "The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe" and also appears in "The Horse and His Boy" and "The Last Battle". He is close friends with Lucy Pevensie and is the first creature she meets in Narnia, as well as the first Narnian to be introduced in the series. Lewis said that the first Narnia story, "The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe", all came to him from a single picture he had in his head of a faun carrying an umbrella and parcels through a snowy wood. In that way, Tumnus was the initial inspiration for the entire Narnia series.

Lucy Pevensie
Lucy Pevensie is a fictional character in C. S. Lewis's "The Chronicles of Narnia" series. She is the youngest of the four Pevensie children, and the first to find the Wardrobe entrance to Narnia in "The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe". Of all the Pevensie children, Lucy is the closest to Aslan. Also, of all the humans who have visited Narnia, Lucy is perhaps the one that believes in Narnia the most. She is ultimately crowned Queen Lucy the Valiant, co-ruler of Narnia along with her two brothers and her sister. Lucy is the central character of the four siblings in the novels. Lucy is a principal character in three of the seven books ("The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe", "Prince Caspian", and "The Voyage of the Dawn Treader"), and a minor character in two others ("The Horse and His Boy" and "The Last Battle").

Georgie Henley
Georgina Helen "Georgie" Henley (born 9 July 1995) is an English actress. She is best known for her portrayal of Lucy Pevensie in "The Chronicles of Narnia" film series.

Sophie Wilcox
Sophie Elizabeth Wilcox (born 2 January 1975 in Croydon, London) is an English actress who is most notable for appearing in the BBC miniseries adaptation of "The Chronicles of Narnia" as Lucy Pevensie when she was 13 years old. She appeared in "The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe" in 1988, as well as its sequel "Prince Caspian and the Voyage of the Dawn Treader" in 1989.

Eustace Scrubb
Eustace Clarence Scrubb is a fictional character in C. S. Lewis's Chronicles of Narnia. He appears in "The Voyage of the Dawn Treader", "The Silver Chair", and "The Last Battle". In "The Voyage of the Dawn Treader", he is accompanied by Edmund and Lucy Pevensie, his cousins. In "The Silver Chair" and "The Last Battle", he is accompanied by Jill Pole, a classmate from his school.

Jeffrey Perry (British actor)
Jeffrey Harold Perry (13 October 1948 – 4 February 2012) was a British stage and screen actor. Born in Barrow-in-Furness, Lancashire and trained at the Guildhall School of Music and Drama, he worked extensively for the Royal Exchange in Manchester. He may be best known to television audiences as Mr. Tumnus in the 1988 version of "The Lion, the Witch, and the Wardrobe", which was part of the BBC's "Chronicles of Narnia" TV miniseries.

The Chronicles of Narnia: Prince Caspian
The Chronicles of Narnia: Prince Caspian is a 2008 high fantasy film based on "Prince Caspian", the second published, fourth chronological novel in C. S. Lewis's epic fantasy series, "The Chronicles of Narnia". It is the second in "The Chronicles of Narnia" film series from Walden Media, following "" (2005). The four Pevensie children (William Moseley, Anna Popplewell, Skandar Keynes, and Georgie Henley) return to Narnia to aid Prince Caspian (Ben Barnes) in his struggle with the "secret" help of Aslan (Liam Neeson) for the throne against his corrupt uncle, King Miraz (Sergio Castellitto). The film was released on May 16, 2008 in the United States and on June 26, 2008 in the United Kingdom.

Mainz Psalter
The Mainz Psalter was the second major book printed with movable type in the West; the first was the Gutenberg Bible. It is a psalter commissioned by the Mainz archbishop in 1457. The Psalter introduced several innovations: it was the first book to feature a printed date of publication, a printed colophon, two sizes of type, printed decorative initials, and the first to be printed in three colours. The colophon also contains the first example of a printer's mark. It was the first important publication issued by Johann Fust and Peter Schoeffer following their split from Johannes Gutenberg.

C. S. Lewis
Clive Staples Lewis (29 November 1898 – 22 November 1963) was a British novelist, poet, academic, medievalist, literary critic, essayist, lay theologian, broadcaster, lecturer, and Christian apologist. He held academic positions at both Oxford University (Magdalen College, 1925–1954) and Cambridge University (Magdalene College, 1954–1963). He is best known for his works of fiction, especially "The Screwtape Letters", "The Chronicles of Narnia", and "The Space Trilogy", and for his non-fiction Christian apologetics, such as "Mere Christianity", "Miracles", and "The Problem of Pain".

Lucy Barfield
Lucy Barfield (2 November 1935 – 3 May 2003) was the godchild of C.S. Lewis. "The Lion the Witch and the Wardrobe" is dedicated to Lucy, who also lent her name to the book's heroine, Lucy Pevensie.
thoughts: The book series "The Chronicles of Narnia" features the characters Lucy Pevensie and Mr. Tumnus. The first scene of Narnia is described in the fictional place of Lantern Waste, where Lucy Pevensie and Mr. Tumnus meet. Mr. Tumnus is a faun and the first Narnian to be introduced in the series, serving as the initial inspiration for the entire Narnia series. Lucy Pevensie is the youngest of the four Pevensie children and is the first to find the Wardrobe entrance to Narnia. She is a central character in three of the seven books and is ultimately crowned Queen Lucy the Valiant. The character of Lucy Pevensie was dedicated to Lucy Barfield, the godchild of C.S. Lewis. The series was written by C.S. Lewis, a British novelist, poet, and Christian apologist. The series has also been adapted into films, with Georgie Henley portraying Lucy Pevensie in "The Chronicles of Narnia" film series.

The specific book in "The Chronicles of Narnia" where Lucy Pevensie first encounters Mr. Tumnus is "The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe". This is the first book in the series and the first scene of Narnia described in the books.
The place where Lucy Pevensie meets Mr. Tumnus for the first time is inside the wardrobe in the Professor's house, which leads her to the magical land of Narnia.

Lantern Waste
Lantern Waste is a fictional place in "The Chronicles of Narnia" series by C. S. Lewis. It is a wood and is notable as the place where Lucy Pevensie and Mr. Tumnus meet, which is the first scene of Narnia described in the books. The lamppost in the wood is an iconic image of Narnia, and the question of its origin is what convinced Lewis to write more than one book on Narnia. One of King Edmund's titles is "Duke of Lantern Waste".

Lucy Pevensie
Lucy Pevensie is a fictional character in C. S. Lewis's "The Chronicles of Narnia" series. She is the youngest of the four Pevensie children, and the first to find the Wardrobe entrance to Narnia in "The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe". Of all the Pevensie children, Lucy is the closest to Aslan. Also, of all the humans who have visited Narnia, Lucy is perhaps the one that believes in Narnia the most. She is ultimately crowned Queen Lucy the Valiant, co-ruler of Narnia along with her two brothers and her sister. Lucy is the central character of the four siblings in the novels. Lucy is a principal character in three of the seven books ("The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe", "Prince Caspian", and "The Voyage of the Dawn Treader"), and a minor character in two others ("The Horse and His Boy" and "The Last Battle").

Lucy Barfield
Lucy Barfield (2 November 1935 – 3 May 2003) was the godchild of C.S. Lewis. "The Lion the Witch and the Wardrobe" is dedicated to Lucy, who also lent her name to the book's heroine, Lucy Pevensie.

Sophie Wilcox
Sophie Elizabeth Wilcox (born 2 January 1975 in Croydon, London) is an English actress who is most notable for appearing in the BBC miniseries adaptation of "The Chronicles of Narnia" as Lucy Pevensie when she was 13 years old. She appeared in "The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe" in 1988, as well as its sequel "Prince Caspian and the Voyage of the Dawn Treader" in 1989.

Jeffrey Perry (British actor)
Jeffrey Harold Perry (13 October 1948 – 4 February 2012) was a British stage and screen actor. Born in Barrow-in-Furness, Lancashire and trained at the Guildhall School of Music and Drama, he worked extensively for the Royal Exchange in Manchester. He may be best known to television audiences as Mr. Tumnus in the 1988 version of "The Lion, the Witch, and the Wardrobe", which was part of the BBC's "Chronicles of Narnia" TV miniseries.

Georgie Henley
Georgina Helen "Georgie" Henley (born 9 July 1995) is an English actress. She is best known for her portrayal of Lucy Pevensie in "The Chronicles of Narnia" film series.

Eustace Scrubb
Eustace Clarence Scrubb is a fictional character in C. S. Lewis's Chronicles of Narnia. He appears in "The Voyage of the Dawn Treader", "The Silver Chair", and "The Last Battle". In "The Voyage of the Dawn Treader", he is accompanied by Edmund and Lucy Pevensie, his cousins. In "The Silver Chair" and "The Last Battle", he is accompanied by Jill Pole, a classmate from his school.

Susan Pevensie
Susan Pevensie is a fictional character in C. S. Lewis's "The Chronicles of Narnia" series. Susan is the elder sister and the second eldest Pevensie child. She appears in three of the seven books—as a child in "The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe" and "Prince Caspian", and as an adult in "The Horse and His Boy". She is also mentioned in "The Voyage of the Dawn Treader" and "The Last Battle". During her reign at the Narnian capital of Cair Paravel, she is known as Queen Susan the Gentle or Queen Susan of the Horn. She was the only Pevensie that survived the train wreck (because she was not on the train or at the station) on Earth which sent the others to Narnia after "The Last Battle".

The Chronicles of Narnia: Prince Caspian
The Chronicles of Narnia: Prince Caspian is a 2008 high fantasy film based on "Prince Caspian", the second published, fourth chronological novel in C. S. Lewis's epic fantasy series, "The Chronicles of Narnia". It is the second in "The Chronicles of Narnia" film series from Walden Media, following "" (2005). The four Pevensie children (William Moseley, Anna Popplewell, Skandar Keynes, and Georgie Henley) return to Narnia to aid Prince Caspian (Ben Barnes) in his struggle with the "secret" help of Aslan (Liam Neeson) for the throne against his corrupt uncle, King Miraz (Sergio Castellitto). The film was released on May 16, 2008 in the United States and on June 26, 2008 in the United Kingdom.
thoughts: The relevant book in The Chronicles of Narnia where Lucy Pevensie and Mr. Tumnus's meeting is described is "The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe". This is the first book in the series and it is where Lucy first discovers the entrance to Narnia and meets Mr. Tumnus in the Lantern Waste.

The scene where Lucy Pevensie first meets Mr. Tumnus can be found in "The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe" by C.S. Lewis. It takes place in Lantern Waste, which is the first scene of Narnia described in the books. This meeting is the initial introduction to Narnia in the series.
The place where Lucy Pevensie and Mr. Tumnus meet is Lantern Waste.

Lewis's epic fantasy series, "The Chronicles of Narnia". It is the second in "The Chronicles of Narnia" film series from Walden Media, following "" (2005). The four Pevensie children (William Moseley, Anna Popplewell, Skandar Keynes, and Georgie Henley) return to Narnia to aid Prince Caspian (Ben Barnes) in his struggle with the "secret" help of Aslan (Liam Neeson) for the throne against his corrupt uncle, King Miraz (Sergio Castellitto). The film was released on May 16, 2008 in the United States and on June 26, 2008 in the United Kingdom.

Eustace Scrubb
Eustace Clarence Scrubb is a fictional character in C. S. Lewis's Chronicles of Narnia. He appears in "The Voyage of the Dawn Treader", "The Silver Chair", and "The Last Battle". In "The Voyage of the Dawn Treader", he is accompanied by Edmund and Lucy Pevensie, his cousins. In "The Silver Chair" and "The Last Battle", he is accompanied by Jill Pole, a classmate from his school.

Susan Pevensie
Susan Pevensie is a fictional character in C. S. Lewis's "The Chronicles of Narnia" series. Susan is the elder sister and the second eldest Pevensie child. She appears in three of the seven books—as a child in "The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe" and "Prince Caspian", and as an adult in "The Horse and His Boy". She is also mentioned in "The Voyage of the Dawn Treader" and "The Last Battle". During her reign at the Narnian capital of Cair Paravel, she is known as Queen Susan the Gentle or Queen Susan of the Horn. She was the only Pevensie that survived the train wreck (because she was not on the train or at the station) on Earth which sent the others to Narnia after "The Last Battle".

The meeting between Lucy Pevensie and Mr. Tumnus takes place in Lantern Waste, which is the first scene of Narnia described in the books. This meeting is the first encounter Lucy has with a Narnian creature and sets the stage for the rest of the series.

question: What is the name of the place in The Chronicles of Narnia where Lucy Pevensie and Mr. Tumnus meet?

nodes.instruction: Find a summary or description of 'The Chronicles of Narnia' series.

Find a detailed summary of the identified book from the series.

Extract the name of the place where they meet from the located scene.

Next, it focuses on that specific book and drills down to find the exact scene description in the plot where Lucy and Mr. Tumnus meet, which occurs at the lamp-post at the edge of Narnia. The final extraction step identifies this place within the scene details.

retrieved_passages:
Lantern Waste
Lantern Waste is a fictional place in "The Chronicles of Narnia" series by C. S. Lewis. It is a wood and is notable as the place where Lucy Pevensie and Mr. Tumnus meet, which is the first scene of Narnia described in the books. The lamppost in the wood is an iconic image of Narnia, and the question of its origin is what convinced Lewis to write more than one book on Narnia. One of King Edmund's titles is "Duke of Lantern Waste".

Mr. Tumnus
Tumnus is a fictional character in C. S. Lewis' series "The Chronicles of Narnia". He is featured prominently in "The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe" and also appears in "The Horse and His Boy" and "The Last Battle". He is close friends with Lucy Pevensie and is the first creature she meets in Narnia, as well as the first Narnian to be introduced in the series. Lewis said that the first Narnia story, "The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe", all came to him from a single picture he had in his head of a faun carrying an umbrella and parcels through a snowy wood. In that way, Tumnus was the initial inspiration for the entire Narnia series.

Lucy Pevensie
Lucy Pevensie is a fictional character in C. S. Lewis's "The Chronicles of Narnia" series. She is the youngest of the four Pevensie children, and the first to find the Wardrobe entrance to Narnia in "The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe". Of all the Pevensie children, Lucy is the closest to Aslan. Also, of all the humans who have visited Narnia, Lucy is perhaps the one that believes in Narnia the most. She is ultimately crowned Queen Lucy the Valiant, co-ruler of Narnia along with her two brothers and her sister. Lucy is the central character of the four siblings in the novels. Lucy is a principal character in three of the seven books ("The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe", "Prince Caspian", and "The Voyage of the Dawn Treader"), and a minor character in two others ("The Horse and His Boy" and "The Last Battle").

Georgie Henley
Georgina Helen "Georgie" Henley (born 9 July 1995) is an English actress. She is best known for her portrayal of Lucy Pevensie in "The Chronicles of Narnia" film series.

Sophie Wilcox
Sophie Elizabeth Wilcox (born 2 January 1975 in Croydon, London) is an English actress who is most notable for appearing in the BBC miniseries adaptation of "The Chronicles of Narnia" as Lucy Pevensie when she was 13 years old. She appeared in "The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe" in 1988, as well as its sequel "Prince Caspian and the Voyage of the Dawn Treader" in 1989.

Jeffrey Perry (British actor)
Jeffrey Harold Perry (13 October 1948 – 4 February 2012) was a British stage and screen actor. Born in Barrow-in-Furness, Lancashire and trained at the Guildhall School of Music and Drama, he worked extensively for the Royal Exchange in Manchester. He may be best known to television audiences as Mr. Tumnus in the 1988 version of "The Lion, the Witch, and the Wardrobe", which was part of the BBC's "Chronicles of Narnia" TV miniseries.

Susan Pevensie
Susan Pevensie is a fictional character in C. S. Lewis's "The Chronicles of Narnia" series. Susan is the elder sister and the second eldest Pevensie child. She appears in three of the seven books—as a child in "The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe" and "Prince Caspian", and as an adult in "The Horse and His Boy". She is also mentioned in "The Voyage of the Dawn Treader" and "The Last Battle". During her reign at the Narnian capital of Cair Paravel, she is known as Queen Susan the Gentle or Queen Susan of the Horn. She was the only Pevensie that survived the train wreck (because she was not on the train or at the station) on Earth which sent the others to Narnia after "The Last Battle".

Lewis's epic fantasy series, "The Chronicles of Narnia". It is the second in "The Chronicles of Narnia" film series from Walden Media, following "" (2005). The four Pevensie children (William Moseley, Anna Popplewell, Skandar Keynes, and Georgie Henley) return to Narnia to aid Prince Caspian (Ben Barnes) in his struggle with the "secret" help of Aslan (Liam Neeson) for the throne against his corrupt uncle, King Miraz (Sergio Castellitto). In "The Voyage of the Dawn Treader", he is accompanied by Edmund and Lucy Pevensie, his cousins. In "The Silver Chair" and "The Last Battle", he is accompanied by Jill Pole, a classmate from his school.

Lucy Barfield
Lucy Barfield (2 November 1935 – 3 May 2003) was the godchild of C.S. Lewis. "The Lion the Witch and the Wardrobe" is dedicated to Lucy, who also lent her name to the book's heroine, Lucy Pevensie.

William Harrison (priest)
William Harrison (18 April 1534 – 24 April 1593) was an English clergyman, whose "Description of England" was produced as part of the publishing venture of a group of London stationers who produced Raphael Holinshed's "Chronicles" (London 1577). His contribution to Holinshed's work drew heavily on the earlier work of John Leland.
thoughts: "The Chronicles of Narnia" is a series of seven high fantasy novels written by C. S. Lewis. The series is set in the fictional land of Narnia and features various characters such as Lucy Pevensie, Edmund Pevensie, Susan Pevensie, and Peter Pevensie, who discover the magical world of Narnia through a wardrobe. The series follows their adventures and the battles between good and evil in Narnia, with the presence of the lion Aslan, who serves as a central figure in the series. The books have been adapted into films, with "The Chronicles of Narnia: Prince Caspian" being one of the adaptations. The series has gained popularity for its imaginative storytelling and themes of bravery, loyalty, and the battle between good and evil.

The book where Lucy Pevensie first meets Mr. Tumnus in 'The Chronicles of Narnia' series is "The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe". This is the first scene of Narnia described in the books, and it is where Lucy Pevensie, the youngest of the four Pevensie children, first enters Narnia and meets Mr. Tumnus, a faun.

"The Chronicles of Narnia" is a series of high fantasy novels by C. S. Lewis, with "The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe" being the first book in the series. The story follows the adventures of the Pevensie siblings as they discover the magical land of Narnia. The character of Mr. Tumnus, a faun, is the first creature that the youngest sibling, Lucy Pevensie, meets in Narnia. Tumnus plays a significant role in the series and is the initial inspiration for the entire Narnia series.

Lucy Pevensie is the central character of the four siblings in the novels and is the first to find the Wardrobe entrance to Narnia. She is known for her unwavering belief in Narnia and her close relationship with Aslan, the lion. Sophie Wilcox and Jeffrey Perry are notable for their portrayals of Lucy Pevensie and Mr. Tumnus, respectively, in the BBC miniseries adaptation of "The Chronicles of Narnia".

Susan Pevensie, the elder sister, also plays a significant role in the series and is known as Queen Susan the Gentle during her reign in Narnia. The character of Susan is featured in several of the books in the series.

The Chronicles of Narnia: Prince Caspian is a film adaptation of the second published, fourth chronological novel in the series. The film follows the Pevensie children as they return to Narnia to aid Prince Caspian in his struggle for the throne against his corrupt uncle, King Miraz.

Lantern Waste is a fictional place in Narnia and is notable as the location where Lucy Pevensie and Mr. Tumnus first meet. The lamppost in the wood is an iconic image of Narnia and plays a significant role in the series.

Overall, "The Chronicles of Narnia" series is a beloved and enduring fantasy series that continues to captivate readers and audiences with its magical world and memorable characters.

The scene where Lucy Pevensie meets Mr. Tumnus can be found in "The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe" when Lucy first enters Narnia through the wardrobe. This iconic meeting takes place in the Lantern Waste, where Mr. Tumnus, a faun, is the first creature she encounters in Narnia. This meeting sets the stage for the rest of the story and is a pivotal moment in the series.
The place where Lucy Pevensie meets Mr. Tumnus is the Lantern Waste in Narnia.
